rsbNotes.title: Ps 20:1
rsbNotes.text: 20:1 you. The king. The congregation calls upon the Lord to bless the king as he sets out for war. The blessings in these verses are also properly applied to New Testament believers in their battle of faith.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 20:2
rsbNotes.text: 20:2 from the sanctuary. Cf. 1 Kin. 8:44, 45.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 20:5
rsbNotes.text: 20:5 shout for joy over your salvation. The psalms contain hymns of praise sung to God after victories. Two examples are Ps. 24 and 98.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 20:6–8
rsbNotes.text: 20:6–8 Israel will win the battle because of the Lord’s presence. Israel’s trust is rooted in God’s promise to protect His people in warfare when they are obedient to His commands (Deut. 7 and 20).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 20:6
rsbNotes.text: 20:6 anointed. The Davidic king, anticipating the Son of David who reigns forever, Jesus Christ.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 20:7
rsbNotes.text: 20:7 we trust in the name. The believer’s rescue from sin and Satan, like Israel’s deliverance from enemies, is grounded in God’s trustworthiness.
